repnme.cdata!: Sierra Leone - Health and Population Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Health and Population
            Project in Sierra Leone were as follows: overall outcome of
            the project was deficient, and the performance of the Bank
            and the Borrower were rated deficient. Lessons learned from
            the project are: 1) A project that aims at the institutional
            development of two different Government entities, but gives
            only one of them access to project funds, runs the risk of
            seeing the other entity crowded out. In such a case, it
            might be more effective to either have two separate projects
            or to provide both Government entities with a special
            account and access to the credit. This problem may be of
            particular relevance for the population sector which remains
            a highly sensitive area of assistance; 2) cost recovery
            programs and drug revolving funds are unlikely to yield a
            100 percent recovery of costs. They are difficult to operate
            and vulnerable to abuse. Full-fledged management systems and
            measures to reduce the risks need to be designed and set up
            before and not after their establishment; and 3) if projects
            are approved even though a country is threatened by
            subsequent International Development Association (IDA)
            suspensions, adequate precautions need to be taken to reduce
            the possible damage for all parties involved. It should be
            ensured that suppliers are advised to request letters of
            credit so that they are not faced with non-payment in case
            of suspension.

repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - Health and Population Sector
            Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Health and Population Project is
            designed to strengthen the capacity of the Ministry of
            Health (MOH) for planning, management, coordination and
            monitoring, to improve basic health and family planning
            services, and to help develop population policy and programs
            for family planning demand-generation activities. A key
            project objective is to reduce dependence on public
            expenditure to finance developments in the sector by using
            available resources more efficiently and by significantly
            improving cost recovery and cost containment practices. To
            assist in the policy reforms and management improvement
            efforts, the project will provide technical assistance and
            training, equipment, materials, vehicles and incremental
            staff. To strengthen health and family planning service
            delivery, it will finance renovation and equipping of a
            limited number of service facilities and provision of
            essential drugs and medical supplies.
